title: 114_s2160
content: The "Military Enlistment Opportunity Act of 2015" is the short title of the Act. Qualifications for enlistment in the Armed Forces are outlined in the Act. The "Military Enlistment Opportunity Act of 2015" outlines qualifications for enlistment in the Armed Forces, including provisions for additional qualified persons such as aliens with lawful residency and individuals with DACA employment authorization. It also includes a subsection for admission to permanent residence for certain enlistees. The "Military Enlistment Opportunity Act of 2015" allows non-citizens or non-permanent residents who enlist in the armed forces to be adjusted to lawful permanent resident status under certain conditions. The Secretary of Homeland Security can revoke this status if the individual is separated from the military. The "Military Enlistment Opportunity Act of 2015" allows non-citizens or non-permanent residents who enlist in the armed forces to be adjusted to lawful permanent resident status. The Secretary of Homeland Security can revoke this status if the individual is separated from the armed forces under other than honorable conditions before serving for a period aggregating five years. The "Military Enlistment Opportunity Act of 2015" allows non-citizens or non-permanent residents who enlist in the armed forces to be adjusted to lawful permanent resident status. Section 504 of the act outlines the qualifications and exceptions regarding citizenship or residency requirements for enlistment. The table of sections in chapter 31 of the title is updated to reflect these changes. SEC. 3. TREATMENT OF CERTAIN PERSONS AS HAVING SATISFIED ENGLISH AND CIVICS, GOOD MORAL CHARACTER, AND HONORABLE SERVICE AND DISCHARGE REQUIREMENTS FOR NATURALIZATION. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 329B, which pertains to persons who have received an award for engagement in active combat or active participation in combat. For naturalization and continuing citizenship, receiving an award described in subsection (b) allows a person to be treated as having satisfied certain requirements under the law, including serving honorably in the Armed Forces for a specified period and being separated under honorable conditions. The section specifies that individuals who received certain military awards can be considered to have met requirements for naturalization and citizenship if they served honorably and were separated under honorable conditions. It also mentions that individuals separated under other than honorable conditions may have their citizenship revoked. The Secretary of Defense can determine equivalent awards for combat engagement. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents of the Act. The Secretary of Defense can determine equivalent awards for combat engagement, including for persons who have received an award for active combat or active participation in combat.
